author: Claire Heaney
title: Money to be found in mobile for small businesses | Business News | Business and Finance News | |
text:
VICTORIAN small businesses are missing out on a key target audience because their online presence is not mobile friendly, a new report reveals.
Despite more people than ever researching and shopping on the move using phones and other devices, only around a quarter of Victorian businesses have mobile-friendly websites.
The 2015 Sensis e-Business Report of 1000 businesses found that nationally 45 per cent of small and medium businesses had optimised their websites to be mobile friendly, compared with just 26 per cent of Victorian businesses.
“Victorian businesses could well fall behind their interstate counterparts if they don’t look to optimise their websites for mobiles. In April, Google announced changes to its search algorithm that give prominence to websites designed for viewing on mobiles and tablets,” Sensis commercial director Rob Tolliday said.
While Victorian businesses were slow on the mobile uptake they were leading the way in online selling to the world.
The report found that in Victoria, overseas customers were targeted by 15 per cent of businesses, compared to an average of 3 per cent nationally.
The report said 51 per cent of Australian small and medium businesses are selling online with 66 per cent of those making the majority of sales to customers in their local area.
Of the businesses surveyed, 3 per cent said they were connected to the National Broadband Network, up from 2 per cent last year.
The report, which also questioned 800 consumers about their buying habits, found they loved to shop online from overseas businesses.
“Nationally, 21 per cent of consumers’ online purchases are coming from overseas, highlighting the growing problem many Australian retailers face from overseas competition. It will be interesting to see what impact the proposed GST on imported goods under $1000 will have on this figure,” Mr Tolliday said.
“Surprisingly, on the consumer side, men dominated online, spending $6500. This was more than twice as much as women, who spent $2400 for the year. Men bought more video games and takeaway food, whereas women purchased more groceries and cosmetics,” he said.
Just over three out of 10 businesses said they used social media in their business with most saying they had a Facebook page.
